questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of business ethics in real estate?
options: To guide licensees beyond the minimum legal standards
questions.correctAnswer: To guide licensees beyond the minimum legal standards
questions.explanation: Business ethics guide licensees in making decisions that exceed minimum legal standards.

questions.questionText: What is required for offering party incentives to clients?
questions.correctAnswer: Clearly defined and written terms
questions.explanation: Incentives must be clearly defined and in writing to avoid misunderstandings.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee do when practicing outside their area of competence?
options: Refer the transaction or engage a competent party
questions.correctAnswer: Refer the transaction or engage a competent party
questions.explanation: Licensees must refer the transaction or seek assistance when they lack competence.

questions.questionText: What is mediation?
options: A voluntary negotiation facilitated by a neutral third party
A method of setting commission rates
questions.correctAnswer: A voluntary negotiation facilitated by a neutral third party
questions.explanation: Mediation involves a neutral party helping disputants reach a voluntary agreement.

questions.questionText: Who can a real estate licensee pay referral fees to?
options: Wisconsin licensees or non-Wisconsin professionals lawfully engaged in real estate brokerage
questions.correctAnswer: Wisconsin licensees or non-Wisconsin professionals lawfully engaged in real estate brokerage
questions.explanation: Referral fees can only be paid to licensed professionals or those lawfully engaged in real estate brokerage.

questions.questionText: What is arbitration?
options: A voluntary negotiation facilitated by a neutral third party
A process where disputes are resolved by a neutral panel and decisions may be binding or nonbinding
A method of setting commission rates
questions.correctAnswer: A process where disputes are resolved by a neutral panel and decisions may be binding or nonbinding
questions.explanation: Arbitration involves a neutral panel that resolves disputes, which can be binding or nonbinding.

questions.questionText: What type of disputes does REALTOR® arbitration typically handle?
questions.correctAnswer: Contractual disputes between REALTORS®
questions.explanation: REALTOR® arbitration resolves contractual disputes between REALTORS®.

questions.questionText: What is a grievance committee’s role in an ethics complaint?
options: To determine if the complaint warrants a hearing
questions.correctAnswer: To determine if the complaint warrants a hearing
questions.explanation: Grievance committees review complaints to decide if they should proceed to a hearing.

questions.questionText: What can REALTORS® use ombudsman services for?
questions.correctAnswer: To facilitate communication in disputes
questions.explanation: Ombudsman services focus on communication and informal resolution.

questions.questionText: What is the effect of mediation on relationships between disputing parties?
questions.correctAnswer: It typically preserves relationships
questions.explanation: Mediation is non-adversarial and aims to preserve relationships.

questions.questionText: What is a key characteristic of arbitration?
options: Decisions can be binding or nonbinding
It requires a written contract for disputes
It is only used for zoning disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Decisions can be binding or nonbinding
questions.explanation: Arbitration can result in either binding or nonbinding decisions, depending on agreements.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of Wis. Stat. § 452.19 regarding referral fees?
options: To allow unlicensed individuals to receive compensation
To restrict referral fees to licensed or lawfully engaged professionals
To regulate the use of electronic transactions
questions.correctAnswer: To restrict referral fees to licensed or lawfully engaged professionals
questions.explanation: Referral fees are restricted to licensed or lawfully engaged professionals.

questions.questionText: What must a licensee document when engaging assistance for competency?
options: Identity and contribution of the assisting party
questions.correctAnswer: Identity and contribution of the assisting party
questions.explanation: Licensees must document the identity and role of any assisting party.

questions.questionText: What is an advantage of mediation over arbitration?
options: Mediation is less costly and preserves relationships better
Mediation is faster but more expensive
questions.correctAnswer: Mediation is less costly and preserves relationships better
questions.explanation: Mediation is informal, less costly, and preserves relationships better.

questions.questionText: What is required to file a complaint with the DSPS?
questions.correctAnswer: A formal written submission
questions.explanation: Complaints must be submitted in writing through the DSPS process.

questions.questionText: What happens if a grievance committee finds merit in an arbitration request?
options: The request proceeds to a hearing
The matter is referred to a court
questions.correctAnswer: The request proceeds to a hearing
questions.explanation: If the grievance committee finds merit, the request proceeds to a hearing.

questions.questionText: What must a mediation settlement include to finalize the process?
questions.correctAnswer: A written settlement agreement
questions.explanation: Mediation settlements must be documented in writing to be finalized.

questions.questionText: Under what condition can licensees resolve disputes through arbitration?
options: If both parties agree to submit to arbitration
If the dispute involves nonbinding mediation
questions.correctAnswer: If both parties agree to submit to arbitration
questions.explanation: Arbitration requires mutual agreement to proceed.

questions.questionText: How does arbitration differ from civil litigation?
options: Arbitration is faster, less costly, and less formal
Arbitration is more expensive and time-consuming
Arbitration allows appeals in federal court
questions.correctAnswer: Arbitration is faster, less costly, and less formal
questions.explanation: Arbitration is designed to resolve disputes faster and at a lower cost than litigation.

questions.questionText: What must be disclosed in an arbitration agreement for a real estate transaction?
options: Scope and terms of arbitrable disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Scope and terms of arbitrable disputes
questions.explanation: Arbitration agreements should define the scope and terms of disputes subject to arbitration.

questions.questionText: What is a significant disadvantage of civil litigation compared to alternative dispute resolution methods?
options: It is faster but less effective
It is costly, time-consuming, and adversarial
It does not involve legal representation
questions.correctAnswer: It is costly, time-consuming, and adversarial
questions.explanation: Civil litigation is expensive, lengthy, and often damages relationships.

questions.questionText: Under Wis. Admin. Code § REEB 24.03, what is a licensee's duty regarding fraud?
options: Ignore fraudulent behavior if not involved
Protect the public from fraud, misrepresentation, and unethical practices
Report all fraud to the DSPS immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Protect the public from fraud, misrepresentation, and unethical practices
questions.explanation: Licensees must protect the public from fraud and unethical practices.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a stipulation agreement in the DSPS complaint process?
options: To resolve cases without formal hearings
To gather evidence for further investigation
questions.correctAnswer: To resolve cases without formal hearings
questions.explanation: Stipulation agreements help resolve cases without formal proceedings.

questions.questionText: What differentiates nonbinding arbitration from binding arbitration?
options: Nonbinding arbitration does not involve evidence
Nonbinding arbitration results serve as negotiation bases only
Nonbinding arbitration is enforceable by law
questions.correctAnswer: Nonbinding arbitration results serve as negotiation bases only
questions.explanation: Nonbinding arbitration decisions are advisory and serve as negotiation tools.

questions.questionText: What must REALTORS® do when disputes involve both REALTORS® and non-REALTORS®?
options: Arbitrate the dispute through REALTOR® boards
Allow non-REALTORS® to choose dispute resolution methods
questions.correctAnswer: Allow non-REALTORS® to choose dispute resolution methods
questions.explanation: Non-REALTORS® are not bound to arbitration and can choose other methods.

questions.questionText: What must be disclosed in an arbitration agreement for a real estate transaction?
options: Scope and terms of arbitrable disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Scope and terms of arbitrable disputes
questions.explanation: Arbitration agreements should define the scope and terms of disputes subject to arbitration.

questions.questionText: What is the role of the Real Estate Examining Board (REEB) in disciplinary cases?
options: To impose discipline based on administrative hearing outcomes
questions.correctAnswer: To impose discipline based on administrative hearing outcomes
questions.explanation: The REEB reviews decisions and imposes appropriate discipline.
